metadata.title: Getting Started with Open-source Roadmap | by Sara A. Metwalli | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Open-source is probably one of the buzzwords of today’s tech world. As a developer or a data scientist, you’ve probably heard of it before. Even if you were not in a deeply technical field, the…

all_paragraphs: Open-source is probably one of the buzzwords of today’s tech world. As a developer or a data scientist, you’ve probably heard of it before. Even if you were not in a deeply technical field, the chance is you’ve heard someone mention the topic of open-source.
Although many are familiar with the term open-source, it’s not always true that people really know what that term means.

Open-source is a type of software in which the source code of this software is released under a specific copyrights license for others to use, study, change and distribute the software for any purpose — as long as it doesn’t contradict the copyright license.
In Laymen’s terms, that means, when a company or a team builds a service or product, they give others the ability to play with the source code and change things in it.

Contributing to open-source projects have many benefits; it can help you improve your skills, meet new similar-minded people, and build a strong portfolio for future jobs. Another benefit is, if you contribute to open-source often, you will become well known in the community, so, in a sense, you will be a technology influencer.
Well, anyone! Whether you’re a code newbie or someone who has been coding for a while, you can start contributing to open-source projects.

In this article, I will lay out my 10 steps guide — the steps I took — to getting started with open-source. You may have already accomplished some of the steps. In this case, jump into the step you’re currently at.

This step is for those who are curious about open-source yet they don’t have any technical background. Don’t worry. If you’re willing to put in the time, there are no requirements to start building software.

The first thing you need to check before you jump into open-source is your basic programming knowledge. This is the foundation you will need to start building projects. Make sure you know your way around the programming language you’re planning to use in your contribution.
If you want to contribute to Python projects, then knowing Python will help you understand the work that has already been done, and it will be easier for you to extend upon it.
You can't spell open-source without Git. Well, you can, but you know what I mean. Git is the tool that allowed open-source to become a reality. Git is one of the tricky topics to master.

I have been in tech for more than a decade now, and I yet to meet someone who can deal with Git fully without returning to the documentation. However, you don’t need to fully understand the inner dynamic of Git to get started with open-source.
You only need a couple of commands — such as clone, push, pull, commit, know when and how to use them, and voila, you are ready to go.

One of the most difficult aspects when it comes to the tech field, in general, is the huge amount of information out there about any topic. If you try Google “data science libraries,” you will be bombarded with hundreds of thousands of articles talking about this specific topic.
A valuable skill for a developer or a data scientist is to know how to efficiently look for the answers they seek, whether they will Google it or look for it in the documentation or a textbook.
If you want the answer you seek, you need to learn to ask the right questions. This skill will help make your work faster and more efficient.
The majority of the well known and commonly used packages used in data science are open-source packages. Packages like Matplotlib, Numpy, and Scipy.

Reading the documentation of these projects will give you an idea of how such big projects came to be; it will show you the open-source power. It will also give you ideas on what more needs to be done and the opportunities to contribute to those projects.

Moreover, reading their documentation will get familiarized with the various types of licenses and their difference. This knowledge will help you understand the rules and usage of the different licenses to know what to use in your future projects.
Your first contribution is probably going to be the most intimidating. What helped me get over that is making some non-coding contributions before I started making coding ones.

There are many opportunities to contribute to open-source that are not code-based. If you’re a code newbie and still uncomfortable with your coding skills, or someone with no coding skills at all and you want to contribute to open-source, I am here to tell you, you defiantly can!

Many big well-known projects are beginner-friendly and don’t require previous open-source contributions to take you on. Projects such as DuckDuckGo or Habitica are very welcoming for new contributors.

You can also contact the maintainers of your favorite package or service and ask them if they welcome contribution from open-source beginners. This information can also be found on their website and documentation.
Other sources for finding projects are:

Open-source is a community of developers from all over the world that decided to work together and build awesome things. When you contribute to open-source projects, you basically demonstrate that you are willing to join that community.
Socializing with other open-source developers will make you feel like you are a part of a community, a community that will support you when you need and provide you with many opportunities.

You can connect with the community in different ways; you can use slack channels for a specific project you’re working on, such as the slack group for Django, Numpy, or the general Python community slack.

This step is the one that requires the most courage from you! But it is also the most fulfilling step. Once you are comfortable with Git and the programming language you want to use, you contributed using the non-coding contribution to a project. You’re ready for your first code contribution.
Start with a simple feature or bug, maybe something that is not urgent. Take your time, double-check your code, and test well. Then, let it go, create a pull request.
You only need one successful contribution to give you the confidence to keep on contributing.
As you contribute to projects, don’t forget to keep track of your contributions to your portfolio. The contribution you made, the more solid your portfolio will get.

Sometimes, however, it is not about the number of contributions but rather about its quality. That’s why I always recommend that you take your time and produce well-written code. When it comes to software contributions, quality beats quantity at any time.
Here are some websites you can use to build your portfolio:
I know that getting involved in open-source can be intimidating at first, but, just like anything else in life, the best way to get over the intimidation is to jump right to it.
Regardless of the programming language you use/ know, your level of knowledge, or area of expertise, there’s an open-source project out there for you.
So, have confidence in your ability, look for something the excites you, and start contributing. Once you so that, the process gets easier, and the intimation goes away.

There’s no better way for you to enhance your skillset than building things by yourself. Open-source is one of the best things you can do to become a better developer and a more open-minded programmer.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Ph.D. candidate working on Quantum Computing. Traveler, writing lover, science enthusiast, and CS instructor. Get in touch with me bit.ly/2CvFAw6
